items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely for overnight tonight Monday 6th October. This is due to tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth and creating a natural tide locking effect. This will restrict the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Tuesday 7th October.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. Levels may reach Flood Alert again throughout the week due to a set of spring tides, we will update this message as necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60 mAOD at 02:15 on 06/10/25 and 4.14 mAOD at 15:00 on 06/10/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 11 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next 5 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 06/10/25, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast in the early hours of tomorrow morning, 07/10/2025.
Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 00:00 AM on 07/10/2025 at the following locations:
Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 00:45 AM
Eastford Road, peaking around 01:00 AM
Arpley Bridge, peaking around 01:15 AM
It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.   
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings.
Our incident rooms are open and we are closely monitoring the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 07/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale at 11:30 PM on 06/10/2025. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
The lunchtime tide tomorrow, 07/10/25 will not reach flood alert, but the overnight tide on 08/10/25 will pass the flood alert threshold.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 07/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible from 10:30 PM on 06/10/2025. Levels are forecasted to peak at 5.12mAOD.
Further flooding is possible overnight tomorrow from around 11:00 PM due to higher than normal tides.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 07/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely tonight between 11:30pm Monday 6th October and 1:30am, Tuesday 7th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to approaching spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level tonight at Clacton of 2.78mAODN at 12:30am on Tuesday 7th October which is 0.08m above tide tables, wind force 4, Westerly. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Tuesday 7th October.

Levels are now below flood risk thresholds. The following tide on Monday 06 October 2025 at 06:45 am is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold. 

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next couple of days. We continue to monitor the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River and lake levels are receding but remain above the flood alert level .
Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel.
We continue to closely monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 07/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels remain high and are starting to slowly recede following recent heavy rain.
Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
No further flooding is expected.
We continue to closely monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 07/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

River and lake levels remain high and are starting to recede following Storm Amy. 
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site .
There may be some isolated showers throughout today, Monday 06/10/25.
We are continuing to closely monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 07/10/25, or as the situation changes.
